title: Crocus Was a Member of Roger's Crew
theoryText: Based on Crocus's intimate knowledge of Gol D. Roger reaching Laugh Tale and his contemplative thoughts about whether the Straw Hats are 'the ones Roger was waiting for,' many fans theorized that Crocus was actually a member of the Roger Pirates. His role as a doctor and his position at the entrance to the Grand Line seemed too convenient to be coincidental.
author: Multiple fans across forums
evidence: Crocus's detailed knowledge of Roger's journey to Laugh Tale
His mysterious inner monologue about 'the ones we've been waiting for'
His position as lighthouse keeper at the Grand Line entrance
notes: This theory was confirmed later in the series when it was revealed that Crocus served as the ship's doctor for the Roger Pirates during their final voyage.

title: One of the Rumbar Pirates Survived
theoryText: Given that Laboon is still alive and the emphasis placed on the Rumbar Pirates' promise, some fans theorized that at least one member of the crew might have survived and could eventually reunite with Laboon. The emotional weight given to the story suggested it would have a payoff beyond just Luffy's promise.
author: Multiple fans
evidence: The detailed backstory suggested future importance
The promise being left unfulfilled seemed too tragic to be the end
Oda's pattern of paying off emotional setups
notes: This theory was spectacularly confirmed with Brook's introduction during the Thriller Bark arc, where he was revealed as the sole surviving member of the Rumbar Pirates.

title: The Painted Jolly Roger Will Be Important Later
theoryText: Fans speculated that the Straw Hat Jolly Roger painted on Laboon's head would become significant later in the story, possibly as a way to identify Laboon or as proof of Luffy's promise. The emphasis placed on the mark not fading suggested it would serve a narrative purpose beyond the immediate episode.
author: Various fans
evidence: The narrative emphasis on the mark not fading
The promise spanning the entire Grand Line journey
notes: The Jolly Roger becomes emotionally significant when Brook learns about it, proving that Laboon found new friends and has a reason to keep living.

title: Luffy's Promise Represents Inherited Will
theoryText: The promise Luffy makes to Laboon mirrors the inherited will theme that Crocus contemplates regarding Roger. Just as Roger may have been waiting for someone to inherit his will, Luffy inherits the promise to Laboon from the Rumbar Pirates. This theory suggests that promises and inherited will are central to One Piece's philosophy.
author: Multiple theorists
evidence: Crocus's thoughts about inherited will in the same episode
The parallel between Roger's journey and Luffy's
The theme of promises spanning generations
notes: This thematic theory ties into the broader inherited will concept that becomes increasingly important throughout One Piece.
